text.title: Paint a Candy House in Watercolor
text.head: Paint a Candy House in Watercolor
text.p: Toward the end of the year , candy and sweets lurk around every corner . Those visions of sugarplums can be used make art . Doing a painting of a house made of candy is a fun way to indulge without eating too much sugar or spending a lot of cash . The resulting painting will last for years and starts with a simple rectangle .
text.head: Steps

list.item: Assemble your candy references . Shop in the bulk aisle at your grocery store and buy tiny amounts of various candies to use as models . Or , cut pictures of holiday candies , cakes , cookies out of newspapers , magazines and advertisements .

Assemble your art supplies . An 11 ” x 14 ” piece of 140 lb . watercolor paper from a pad , a set of watercolors in a full range of colors , plus black , and an assortment of watercolor brushes . You 'll also need a pencil , eraser , ruler and a fine line Sharpie in black .

Lay out the beginnings of your house . Begin by drawing , in pencil , a rectangle . Use a template if you wish , a box , disk sleeve or other rectangular item . Place this somewhere in the center of your page .

Construct the roof . Find the center of your rectangle at and draw 3 ” vertical line upward . The top end of the line will be the peak of the roof . Construct the roof by drawing a line down each side to form a large triangle . Use a curvy item as a template for roof edge , if you wish .
Return to the body of the house and draw the door . Make it as tall and as wide as you wish . On either side , draw two square windows .

Decorate the house with candy shapes . Look at your references and analyze the various types and styles of candies . These will be your building materials , so look over their various sizes and shapes . Try to picture which candy would look best at what point on your house .

Begin to put candy on the house . Sketch candy of one shape in pencil , repeatedly , to fill one area of your house . For example , for the front , you might have round candies to mimic siding shingles .

Imagine how you want the roof to be . You might use long candies to edge the roof or make it piled with snow -- -marshmallow fluff to mimic snow . By working in pencil , you can make changes easily if one idea does n't work out . Erase and try something else .

Create a suitably sweet environment for your house . Use varied sizes , shapes and colors of candies to make trees , pathways , rocks , signposts , and trimming around the corners of the house and its windows . Candy canes make good lampposts . Green lollipops look a bit like ornamental trees . Long , narrow candies standing in a row resemble a fence . Pile on the candy until much of the house is covered . The landscape ought to be a magical place where candy reigns supreme . Remember to populate the scene . Gingerbread men , women and children look exactly right as residents of a candy house .
Go over the pencil drawing with fine line permanent black marker .
Activate your paints with drops of water . Begin to paint the design . The hard work is done if you have taken time to make your drawing detailed and complete .
Look to see where a color can be used in another part of the design . While you have one color on your brush , use it wherever else it is needed .
Wash in a solid color for a sky . This will be a nice backdrop for the colorful candy . With so much going on in the picture a simple sky will be nice .
Work until the piece looks finished . Allow it to dry and give it another look . If any part needs punching up do it .

text.head: Tips

list.item: Allow the paint to dry before attempting to put another color close to it unless you want the two colors to mingle .

As you paint , work the colors from one spot into other areas of the design . Instead of working in sections and completing one area at a time aim to keep the whole painting involved . This all over approach to color will give a sense of unity to your work , having various shades sprinkled throughout the page .
